children.value: So, a line and a circle. Keep in mind that there may be zero, one, or two solutions...
We can rearrange this into the system:

children.html: mx−y+b=0x2+y2−R2=0mx-y+b=0\\ x^2+y^2-R^2=0mx−y+b=0x2+y2−R2=0
f(x,y)=0f(x,y)=0f(x,y)=0
g(x,y)=0g(x,y)=0g(x,y)=0

f(x,y)\approx f(x_0,y_0) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\bigg\rvert_0 (x-x_0) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\bigg\rvert_0 (y-y_0)\\
g(x,y)\approx g(x_0,y_0) + \frac{\partial g}{\partial x}\bigg\rvert_0 (x-x_0) + \frac{\partial g}{\partial y}\bigg\rvert_0 (y-y_0)

children.value: and can then reframe this as a matrix system, defining

children.html: Δx≡x−x0\Delta x\equiv x-x_0Δx≡x−x0​
Δy=y−y0\Delta y=y-y_0Δy=y−y0​

[∂f∂x∂f∂y∂g∂x∂g∂y]0[ΔxΔy]=[−f−g]0.\begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\\ \frac{\partial g}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial g}{\partial y} \end{bmatrix}_0 \begin{bmatrix} \Delta x\\ \Delta y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -f\\ -g \end{bmatrix}_0.[∂x∂f​∂x∂g​​∂y∂f​∂y∂g​​]0​[ΔxΔy​]=[−f−g​]0​.

children.value: Note that the matrix and right-hand side of this equation are evaluated at the reference location to determine the unknown vector of displacements

children.html: (Δx,Δy)(\Delta x,\Delta y)(Δx,Δy)

children.value: A matrix full of partial derivatives like this is called “The Jacobian”. And in the general linear algebra problem

children.html: Ax=b\mathbf{Ax}=\mathbf{b}Ax=b
b\mathbf{b}b

children.value: is sometimes called “the forcing function” -- in this context, the further

children.value: are, and so there is a greater “push” from the current location.
As was the case with the 1D Newton-Raphson Method, we think about this not as a single step, but rather an iterative scheme:

children.html: [∂f∂x∂f∂y∂g∂x∂g∂y]i[ΔxΔy]i=[−f−g]i\begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\\ \frac{\partial g}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial g}{\partial y} \end{bmatrix}_i \begin{bmatrix} \Delta x\\ \Delta y \end{bmatrix}_i = \begin{bmatrix} -f\\ -g \end{bmatrix}_i[∂x∂f​∂x∂g​​∂y∂f​∂y∂g​​]i​[ΔxΔy​]i​=[−f−g​]i​
xi+1=xi+Δxix_{i+1}=x_i + \Delta x_ixi+1​=xi​+Δxi​
yi+1=yi+Δyiy_{i+1} = y_i +\Delta y_iyi+1​=yi​+Δyi​

children.value: The algorithm matches that of the 1D Newton-Raphson method, but let’s clarify the details.
The two functions and four partial derivatives must be provided as functions, as well as a seed value.
The Jacobian and forcing function of the iterative equation above can be evaluated.
Solving the matrix system tells us how to update our estimation of the solution.
Iterate until convergence or until we give up.
Finding the inverse of a matrix is actually a challenging computational problem. We will learn a computer-friendly version of Gaussian Elimination shortly, but for a small system like this,
